articles.title: South Korea set for hotter-than-average summer
articles.summary: Temperatures in June have a 40% chance of being higher than normal. July and August are forecast to be hotter than previous years. The weather agency points to higher-than-average sea surface temperatures in the tropical western Pacific as the reason for its forecast in June.

articles.title: Letters for May 25: Region needs to work together to fight climate change
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: In Tidewater, we are in real danger from rapid global warming. The local military bases are at risk from sea level rise, and along with them, thousands of jobs. William K. Carter served the Newport News Fire Department with distinction for more than 27 years. He was diagnosed with intrahepatic bile duct carcinoma, a rare and aggressive form of cancer. Virginia's workers' compensation laws do not recognize this type of cancer as a presumptive illness for firefighters.

articles.title: Fashion spinning new yarns from a sheep's head to tail
articles.author: Stephanie Gardiner
articles.summary: Australia rides on the sheep's back, or so goes the time-worn saying about the worth of the meat-and-wool industry. It's estimated to be worth billions of dollars a year to the Australian economy. It is also worth billions to the sheep industry.

articles.title: Fashion spinning new yarns from a sheep's head to tail
articles.author: Stephanie Gardiner
articles.summary: Australia rides on the sheep's back, or so goes the time-worn saying about the worth of the meat-and-wool industry. It's estimated to be worth billions of dollars a year to the Australian economy. It is also worth billions to the sheep industry.

articles.title: Arabian Sea low-pressure system at 985km distance from Karachi
articles.summary: The low-pressure weather system in east-central Arabian Sea has intensified. The system is 985 km southeast of Karachi and located at latitude 17.7 N and longitude 72.5 E. There is no threat to any Pakistani coastal area. The Pakistan Fisherfolk Forum has appealed to fishermen not to venture into the open sea for the next few days.

articles.title: UAE registers record high temperature in May for second day in row
articles.author: TASS
articles.summary: The highest temperature recorded over the country today is 51.6°C in Sweihan (Al Ain) at 13:45 UAE local time (11:45 a.m. GMT). The figure is just 0.4 degrees short of the absolute temperature record in the history of the UAE, registered in 2010 on Al Yasat Island.

articles.title: Scorching Heat in Pakistan
articles.author: Professor Khalid Mahmood
articles.summary: This summer, large parts of Pakistan are reeling under an intense and prolonged heatwave. People living in small homes with tin roofs, with limited or no access to electricity, clean drinking water, or cooling systems are at serious risk. The elderly are at a high risk of strokes, as the heat concentrates the blood and puts additional stress on the cardiovascular system. There is a rise in kidney stone formation during hot weather. There are practical and low-cost steps that can help prevent many heat-related health issues.

articles.title: Manitoba First Nation evacuating some residents due to heavy smoke from nearby wildfire
articles.author: Devon McKendrick
articles.summary: There is a wildfire burning near Cross Lake on May 22, 2025. The smoke is billowing from the flames. The fire is not under control yet. The area is covered in thick smoke. The wildfire is burning on the edge of the Cross Lake area.

articles.title: The NSW floods have already been linked to climate change. Scientists are debating if that's too quick
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: World Weather Attribution has conducted eight attribution studies this year, including for the Los Angeles fires in January, South Korean bushfires in February, and a Central Asia heatwave in March. ClimaMeter uses a well-established method of comparing recent weather events with similar atmospheric configurations over the past four decades. Professor Emeritus David Karoly has some concerns about the methodology of the Cyclone Alfred study.

articles.title: The Essex towns and villages at risk of being underwater by 2030
articles.author: Matt Lee
articles.summary: Essex could be submerged underwater within 16 years due to rising sea levels due to climate change. Key areas at risk include Foulness Island, Tilbury, Stanford-le-Hope, and Heybridge. Canvey Island and significant portions of the Dengie peninsula are also projected to be submerged within 2060.

articles.title: Pakistan's highlights climate change at Venice architecture exhibit
articles.author: Entertainment Desk
articles.summary: Pakistan Pavilion is at the 19th International Architecture Exhibition – La Biennale di Venezia. Its installation (Fr)Agile Systems seeks to explore the drastic impact of climate change. Pakistan contributes less than one percent to global carbon emissions. The 2022 floods alone affected over 30 million people across the country. The rock salt at the heart of the Pavilion represents both agility and fragility.

articles.title: Florida Keys face highest hurricane risk, Monroe official warns: "Run from the water"
articles.summary: Monroe County has a new emergency operations center and a new seawater desalination water treatment plant to prepare for the upcoming hurricane season. Hurricane Irma devastated the Florida Keys with winds up to 132 mph, destroying around 1,180 homes and seriously damaging another 3,000.

articles.title: Solution in the Swamps
articles.author: Krishna Gupta
articles.summary: Coastal wetlands are important for climate change mitigation and adaptation. They absorb a lot of carbon and are a bulwark against cyclones and storms. They are also an excellent habitat for fish, reptiles, mammals, birds, and a variety of invertebrate organisms. They support subsistence livelihoods like fishing in poor countries of Asia and Africa and prevent coastal erosion.

articles.title: ‘Wings Across the World: Protecting Migratory Birds Together'
articles.summary: Migratory birds are essential for the health of ecosystems. They spread seeds, pollinate plants and regulate insect populations. About 20% of bird species are thought to be migratory and their yearly travels result in a redistribution of bird diversity that drastically alters the composition of avian communities around the planet. India harbours over 1349 of the 2274 migratory bird species worldwide, accounting for 59.32% of the total migratory birds population.

articles.title: MEA Justifies Putting On Hold Indus Waters Treaty: ‘Pakistan Kept Goodwill In Abeyance'
articles.author: News18
articles.summary: The Ministry also said that changing ground realities with respect to climate change and glacial melt calls for a renegotiation of the treaty and it's time to renegotiate the treaty with the UNFCCC. The UNFCC is responsible for negotiating the treaty on climate change.

articles.title: 'Climate risk' hype overstates threats: Real culprits are real estate growth and density
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: 'Climate risk' hype overstates threats. Real culprits are real estate growth and densification. Media amplifies the myth, clouds the facts. Media often frame weather disasters as climate-driven 'new normals'. FirstStreet's report warns mortgage lenders could face $5.4 billion in climate-related losses by 2035.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Carney open to changing green laws to boost energy projects  How a warming planet could affect the taste of wine
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: There's news concerning climate change and biodiversity loss in B.C. and around the world. Vancouver aims to grow urban forest canopy, but doesn't expect the promised 100,000 new trees soon. Global average temperature in 2023 reached 1.48 C higher than the pre-industrial average.

articles.title: Tackling heat: Planning to beat the invisible disaster
articles.author: Arunabha Ghosh
articles.summary: In India, the very notion of summer is being rewritten by climate change in 2025. About 2.2 billion children will be exposed to frequent heatwaves by 2050. The equivalent of 35 million jobs could be lost in India by 2030 due to heat stress. Heat is deeply contextual and needs to be addressed on a ward-by-ward basis.

articles.title: From eco-anxiety to emotional fatigue: How climate change is affecting mental health
articles.author: Trisha Mahajan
articles.summary: Climate change can affect mental health in many ways. Dr Radhika Goyal and Chetna Arora talk to TOI about the psychological and social consequences of climate change. They talk about coping with eco-anxiety and building emotional resilience. Dr Goyal advises people to acknowledge their anxiety and seek help.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6C
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The highest temperature in the United Arab Emirates on Saturday was 51.6 degrees Celsius in Sweihan. The highest ever temperature recorded in the UAE since documentation began in 2003 was reported at 52C on Abu Dhabi's Al Yasat Island in 2010. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change. The UAE is host of the COP28 climate talks in 2023.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6C
articles.author: AFP AFP
articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates has breached its May temperature record for the second day in a row, hitting 51.6 degrees Celsius on Saturday. It is within touching distance of the highest ever temperature recorded in the country, which was recorded in Al Ain at 13:45 local time (0945 GMT).

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6 celsius
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The temperature in Sweihan (Al Ain) hit 51.6 degrees celsius on Saturday, within touching distance of the highest ever temperature recorded in the UAE. The highest temperature recorded on Abu Dhabi's Al Yasat Island in 2010 was 52 celsius. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is particularly vulnerable to climate change. The UAE is host of the COP28 climate talks in 2023.

articles.title: V.I. Lenin: Imperialism is epoch of crises, wars and revolutions
articles.author: The Militant
articles.summary: This feature is an excerpt from 'Capitalism's Long Hot Winter Has Begun,' by Jack Barnes, national secretary of the Socialist Workers Party. It's the title article in New International no. 12, issues 7, 10, 11 and 12 of the New International.

articles.title: Extreme weather cycles change underwater light at Tahoe
articles.author: Kat Kerlin
articles.summary: Lake Tahoe is experiencing large-scale shifts in ultraviolet radiation (UV) as climate change intensifies wet and dry extremes in the region. Already subscribed?Originally published on May 24, 2025 at 8:00 AM PDT.    Back to Mail Online home.

articles.title: Thousands of animal species face ‘existential crisis' amid climate change, OSU study says
articles.author: Michaela Bourgeois
articles.summary: Study led by Oregon State University's William Ripple found that more than 3,500 animal species are threatened by climate change. The study was published Tuesday in the journal of the International Union for Conservation of Nature. The analysis reveals 'huge gaps' in fully understanding risks to the animal kingdom.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6C
articles.author: Arab News
articles.summary: The highest temperature recorded over the UAE was 51.6C in Sweihan (Al Ain) on Saturday. It was 1.2C hotter than the temperature recorded on Friday in the Abu Dhabi area. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: From eco-anxiety to emotional fatigue: How climate change is affecting mental health
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Eco-anxiety is a chronic worry about the planet's future especially prevalent among younger generations. It is a growing and often overlooked crisis that is deepening the impact of climate change on mental health, according to the author's research.  He writes that it is also a growing phenomenon that is affecting mental health.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6 deg C
articles.summary: The highest temperature in the UAE on May 24 was 51.6 degrees C in Sweihan (Al Ain). It was 1.2 degrees C hotter than the temperature recorded on May 23 in the Abu Dhabi area. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: UAE breaks May heat record with scorching 51.6C
articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates registered a sizzling 51.5 degrees Celsius on Saturday, breaking its May temperature record for the second day in a row. The highest temperature recorded over the country today is 51.6 degrees Celsius in Sweihan (Al Ain) at 13:45 UAE local time (0945 GMT). The desert nation lies in one of the world's hottest regions and is at risk of severe heat waves due to climate change.

articles.title: UAE breaks May heat record with scorching 51.6C
articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.summary: The highest temperature in Sweihan (Al Ain) was 51.6 degrees Celsius on Saturday. It was 1.2 degrees Celsius hotter than the temperature recorded on Friday in the Abu Dhabi area. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: UAE hits sizzling record May temperature of 51.6C
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The highest temperature in Sweihan (Al Ain) was 51.6 degrees Celsius on Saturday. It was 1.2 degrees Celsius hotter than on Friday. The desert nation lies in one of the planet's hottest regions and is vulnerable to climate change. The number of extremely hot days has nearly doubled globally in the past three decades.

articles.title: Solution set for covered bridge closure in Sackville, N.B.
articles.author: Derek Haggett
articles.summary: Wheaton Covered Bridge near Sackville, N.B., has been closed since July 11, 2024. It's expected to be repaired in the next 10 to 15 years. It will be replaced by a new bridge in the future. The current one is due to be completed in 2024.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature
articles.summary: The highest temperature in the UAE on Saturday was 51.6 degrees Celsius in Sweihan. It was 1.2 degrees Celsius hotter than on Friday in the Abu Dhabi area. The number of extremely hot days has nearly doubled globally in the past three decades.

articles.title: Trump Tries to Make Sure States Don't Fight Climate Change Either
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Nilgiris district administration calls off trekking expeditions on May 25 and 26
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: IMD has sounded red alert for Nilgiris. The district administration has called off 'Trek Tamil Nadu' expeditions on May 25 and 26 and has suspended boating in Ooty Lake for three days. Udhagamandalam, Gudalur and Pandalur areas have been witnessing moderate rainfall since Saturday evening.

articles.title: Egypt's Heatwave Expected to Ease by Sunday After Scorching Heatwave
articles.author: Farah Abbas
articles.summary: Egypt is experiencing an intense heatwave from Saturday to Monday. The heatwave is expected to end on Tuesday. The Eastern Mediterranean and Middle East region is warming nearly twice as fast as the global average. Egypt has developed a National Climate Change Strategy to address climate change.

articles.title: Pinellas Co. parks still recovering from storm damage
articles.author: Sophia Fanning
articles.summary: Pinellas County parks are still recovering from last year's hurricanes. Lake Seminole Park shelter 3 is closed. Madiera Beach Access parking lot and access area are closed for major repairs. Weedon Island Preserve fishing pier has reopened as of Friday, May 23.

articles.title: Severe weather alert causes Mombasa beaches to be closed
articles.author: Samson Nderi
articles.summary: All public beaches in Mombasa have been closed because of a severe weather alert. The measure extends to the suspension of all ocean-based commercial and recreational activities, such as fishing and water sports. Construction activities have been temporarily halted across the county due to the high risk posed by wind-related hazards.

articles.title: Experts issue warning as devastating shocks fuel rise in food prices: 'Pushing families deeper into crisis'
articles.author: Yei Ling Ma
articles.summary: Extreme climate conditions in Somalia are causing increased food crop failures and livestock deaths, which are driving up food prices. More than half of Somalia's population lives below the poverty line, and 24% of the entire country has reached a crisis stage. 1.7 million children aged 5 or under will suffer from acute malnutrition this year, with almost two-thirds of these cases in southern Somalia.

articles.title: Pakistan put in abeyance principles guiding Indus Waters Treaty: MEA
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The MEA has said changes in the ground situation, including climate change and melting of glaciers, have made a renegotiation of the treaty's terms imperative, according to the MEA. The MEA also said that engineering techniques and climate change have changed the situation on the ground.

articles.title: The UK wildfire warning system as climate change drives hot temperatures
articles.author: Sally Guyoncourt
articles.summary: There have been record numbers of wildfires in the UK this year due to climate change. The Peak District and South Pennines have put up wildfire warning signs for the first time. University of Manchester has been working on a project which could provide the UK with its first 'Fire Danger Rating System'.

articles.title: Rajasthan heatwave: Jaisalmer hits 48°C, rain forecast in parts
articles.summary: There is a heatwave in northwestern Rajasthan, particularly in Sri Ganganagar. The IMD has warned that the dry and hot conditions are likely to worsen the already dry climate of the region. The heatwave is expected to last for the next two to three days.

articles.title: Spring in the UK has been so dry and warm. Will the good weather return?
articles.author: Simon H. Lee
articles.summary: April was the sunniest since records began in 1910, followed the third-sunniest March, and both months saw temperatures well above average nationwide. On May 1, the temperature reached 29.3C in Kew Gardens in London, a new record for the date. The UK has seen half its usual amount of rainfall for March and April.

articles.title: UAE hits highest May temperature at 51.6˚C
articles.author: Observer Web Team
articles.summary: The highest temperature for May is 50.4 degrees Celsius recorded in Al Shawamekh (Abu Dhabi) at 14:30 local time on Friday. It topped the highest temperature of 50.2 degrees recorded in May 2009. The National Center of Meteorology started recording May's temperatures in 2003.

articles.title: Nepal urgently needs National Climate Change Assessments
articles.author: Dr. Maheswar Rupakheti
articles.summary: Nepal is living with the climate crisis. Its mountainous terrain and socio-economic fabric render it acutely vulnerable to its impacts. Nepal needs to institutionalize periodic National Climate Change Assessment (NCCA). NCCA is conducted every 5 to 10 years. Nepal ranks 69th on the latest Germanwatch Global Climate Risk Index.

articles.title: Sea Level Rise Will Cause 'Catastrophic Inland Migration'
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: Sea level rise will become unmanageable at 1.5C of global heating and lead to 'catastrophic inland migration', the scientists behind a new study have warned. This scenario may unfold even if the average level of heating over the last decade of 1.2C continues into the future. The loss of ice from the giant Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets has quadrupled since the 1990s due to the climate crisis and is the principal driver of sea level rise.

articles.title: Lawmakers call for urgent review of Climate Change Act
articles.author: Allan Kisia
articles.summary: Lawmakers and National Treasury officials met in Naivasha for a climate action workshop. They discussed the urgent review of Kenya's Climate Change Act 2016. Kenya ratified the Paris Agreement in 2016 and is committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels by 2030.

articles.title: Mozambique on the Brink: UN Warns of Deepening Humanitarian Crisis
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Mozambique is in a humanitarian crisis. 25,000 people have been displaced in the last few weeks, and nearly 1.3 million people have already been uprooted by protracted violence, successive cyclones, and prolonged drought conditions. The humanitarian crisis is intertwined with a deepening economic downturn. Humanitarian organizations are raising urgent alarms as funding continues to dwindle.

articles.title: Ben Davidson
articles.author: James Delingpole
articles.summary: There is an imminent 'flip' in the earth's magnetic poles. Ben Davidson, host of SpaceWeatherNews, tries to convince James to build a bunker. The episode goes in unexpected directions and will entertain you greatly.   Â

articles.title: Gender-transformative climate action framework rooted in feminist theory & justice: Research paper
articles.author: Neel Kamal
articles.summary: A new paper in the Journal of Human Rights and Social Work explores a novel way of understanding the climate crisis using ideas from feminist thinking and climate justice. It calls for a radical shift in climate change policy and action. The framework lays out five interconnected strategies: building feminist leadership, expanding social protection, supporting women-led cooperatives and amplifying regional-language climate media.

articles.title: UAE hits hottest May on record at 50.4°C
articles.author: TDT
articles.summary: The highest temperature for May in the UAE was 50.4 degrees Celsius in Al Shawamekh (Abu Dhabi) at 14:30 local time. It is the highest for May since the National Center of Meteorology started keeping records in 2003. The previous highest temperature was 50°C recorded in May 2009.

articles.title: Over 50% Indians ‘very worried' about climate impacts: Survey
articles.author: Neel Kamal
articles.summary: As the climate warms, extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and severe across India. The Yale Program on Climate Change Communication and CVoter surveyed 10,751 people in India from Dec 5, 2024, to Feb 18, 2025. Most respondents said they personally experienced at least one extreme weather event or related impact in the past 12 months.

articles.title: New Moon and Perigee to Trigger Tidal Floods in West Java's Shores, BMKG Says
articles.author: Anwar Siswadi
articles.summary: BMKG has issued an early warning for potential tidal floods in the southern coastal regions of West Java. The floods are projected to hit the region due to the new moon phase from May 25 to 31 and the perigee phenomenon. High waves from 2.5 to 4 meters will be present in the Indian Ocean west of Aceh, Mentawai Islands, and Lampung. Sailors are warned of strong winds in the waters of southern Central Java, Yogyakarta, East Java, Bali, and East Nusa Tenggara.

articles.title: Is Karachi's Coastal Areas in danger? Arabian Sea Low-Pressure System under watch
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: A low-pressure weather system in east-central Arabian Sea is gaining momentum and is currently located around 1000 km southeast of Karachi. The system is expected to develop into a depression within the next 24 hours and move northwards toward India. It is fueled by warm sea surface temperatures, which could cause very hot weather in Karachi.

articles.title: Red Alert in Goa for Heavy Rainfall
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: A low-pressure system over the east-central Arabian Sea has triggered a red alert for Goa. The weather system is also expected to bring heavy to very heavy rainfall over Gujarat, the Konkan region, Karnataka, and Kerala for the next seven days. The North Goa District Disaster Management Authority convened a preparedness meeting on Friday to evaluate emergency response measures and enhance coordination among key agencies.

articles.title: Over 50% Indians ‘very worried' about climate impacts: Survey
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: As the climate warms, extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and severe across India. Indians recently experienced extreme heat waves, floods, water shortages, and irregular monsoon patterns. These events not only harm people but also cause environmental damage as well as economic losses.

articles.title: Our farmers are leading the fight against climate change
articles.author: Shahrina Akhtar
articles.summary: Farmers in Bangladesh are adapting to climate change. They are pioneering low-cost, climate-smart, and scalable solutions. According to the World Bank, nearly 1.33 crore Bangladeshis may be displaced by climate-induced stress by 2050. Agriculture employs over 40 percent of the workforce and contributes 11.2 percent to GDP.

articles.title: Map pinpoints the 25 UK seaside towns predicted to be underwater in 2030
articles.author: Lauran O'Toole
articles.summary: The future is looking bleak for several UK seaside towns, with a concerning number predicted to be underwater in 2030. Large swathes of the Lincolnshire and Norfolk coasts are set to be affected alongside parts of Kent. London is not safe from rising water levels either, with the greatest risk occurring along the River Thames.

articles.title: Penguin poo may fight climate change
articles.summary: Penguin poop may be playing a key role in keeping climate change in check over Antarctica, according to new research published Thursday by USA Today. The research was published in the journal "The Journal of Climate Change Research".   It was published on Thursday.

articles.title: 'Climate inaction will increase costs for Glasgow's households'
articles.author: Martha Wardrop
articles.summary: Scottish Greens are calling for urgent action to reduce carbon emissions to meet the 2045 net-zero carbon emissions target. Global Witness estimates that the costs of climate breakdown in the UK amount to an estimated £3,000 per household over the course of 2025. Scottish Greens are also calling for the UK Government to listen to climate experts and fix the broken energy market.

articles.title: What keeps the safety director of the most vulnerable spot in US up at night ...
articles.author: San Francisco Chronicle
articles.summary: The Florida Keys are surrounded by water. The Gulf and Atlantic Ocean are on the Florida Keys' coast. The islands are vulnerable to hurricanes in the 50 U.S. states, as Jimmy Buffett has said.    .   i   in his songs.

articles.title: Sorry, kids. We blew your climate budget - but we really love our SUVs
articles.author: John Sweeney
articles.summary: There is a 50-50 chance of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels. The remaining global carbon budget is 235 billion tonnes of CO2, which will be used up in six years at current rates of emission. Ireland has sought to address these issues in its climate legislation and its adherence to the Paris Agreement of 2015 by a system of legally binding five-yearly carbon budgets. The most recent update of these has been recommended to the Minister for the Environment by the Climate Change Advisory Council.

articles.title: Penguins hailed heroes as their poo 'can save the planet', boffins have explained
articles.author: Aaron Tinney
articles.summary: Penguin poo is helping to reverse some of the effects of global warming as it is packed with ammonia. It rises into the atmosphere and helps form clouds which deflect sunlight and lower temperatures. The impact is most visible in the Antarctic and coastal areas. Britain has had record temperatures for this time of year and a string of heatwaves.

articles.title: What keeps the safety director of the most vulnerable spot in US up at night before hurricane season
articles.author: Mike Schneider
articles.summary: No place is more vulnerable to hurricanes in the 50 U.S. states than the Florida Keys. The chain of islands is surrounded by water, jutting out 120 miles from Florida's mainland to Key West with the Gulf and Atlantic Ocean on either side.

articles.title: What keeps the safety director of the most vulnerable spot in US up at night before hurricane season
articles.author: MIKE SCHNEIDER
articles.summary: No place is more vulnerable to hurricanes in the 50 U.S. states than the Florida Keys, which is home to several hurricane-prone areas.    "The Florida Keys is a hurricane-vulnerable place in the whole of the United States.

articles.title: LETTER: Las Vegas is hotter because of the heat island effect
articles.author: Paul Bagley Las Vegas
articles.summary: There is an increasing heat in Clark and Washoe counties. Yale School of the Environment blames it on climate change. Clark County is growing every year. The removal of grass and trees and installation of fake grass and solar panels contribute to the heat island effect in Clark County.

articles.title: City safe from 'Shakti'
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: The low-pressure system in the eastern central Arabian Sea has intensified. The system is expected to move northwards towards India. There is no threat to the Pakistani coastline. The Pakistan Fisherfolk Forum has appealed to fishermen not to venture into the open sea, citing safety concerns due to high tides.

articles.title: California hummingbird beaks transformed by feeders: 'more tapered and longer'
articles.summary: Anna's hummingbirds have spread their range north from California to British Columbia due to human-made hummingbird feeders. The study was published in Global Change Biology. Nicolas Alexandre, one of the paper's authors, collaborated with 15 other researchers from a cumulative 12 institutions.

articles.title: Bushfires NT: Planned Burn on Arnhem Hwy Verge
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Bushfires NT volunteer brigades will be conducting road verge burning as part of the annual mitigation program. The planned burn is currently underway. The smoke from the fire may affect visibility. Firefighting crews may be working close to the roadside as a precautionary measure.

articles.title: 10 Things To Know About Summer 2025
articles.author: The Press
articles.summary: There is a packed schedule of events in Summer 2025. Road construction and drought conditions could impact burning. Here is a brief look at 10 things to know about Summer 2025 and what to watch out for.       in the list are: Road construction, drought conditions and potential burning.

articles.title: Bushfires NT: Planned Burn on Cox Peninsula Rd
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A planned burn is currently underway. The smoke from the fire may affect visibility. Volunteer brigades will be conducting road verge burning as part of the annual mitigation program. The firefighting crews may be working close to the roadside as a precautionary measure. The alert level is at an alert level.

articles.title: Both conspicuous and ubiquitous, the American robin returns to Alaska on time
articles.author: Ned Rozell
articles.summary: American robins have returned to northern Alaska. The population of the American robin increased by 0.13% per year from 1966 to 2019. Robins are easy to find in Alaska's urban areas and its few hundred villages, but you will hear them very far away from settlements.

articles.title: Seasonal downpour to drench Thailand, flooding expected
articles.author: Puntid Tantivangphaisal
articles.summary: Thailand is forecast to experience significant rainfall in the north, northeast, central, east, and southern western regions. The increased rainfall is attributed to a monsoon trough over northern Thailand and a strengthened southwest monsoon covering the Andaman Sea, Thailand, and the Gulf of Thailand.

articles.title: From lingering cold to early heat, Canadians sick of lousy spring weather
articles.summary: Canadians are frustrated with the unusual spring weather. Unseasonably cold temperatures in central and eastern Canada and premature heat in parts of the West are the main reasons for the frustration.   Â   in the West it's been very warm.

articles.title: From boiling hot to freezing cold: Climate crisis sparks sudden temperature changes
articles.author: Mary Wangari
articles.summary: Rapid unusual temperature shifts triggered by global warming could endanger human health and the environment worldwide. Low-income countries will bear the brunt as their exposure to rapid temperature shifts exceeds the global average by up to six times. Global analysis which examined historical data between 1961-2100 showed that over the last six decades, temperature flips have become faster by 78%.

articles.title: Climate Change Hits Home
articles.author: Amina Amin Kanju
articles.summary: El Nino affects global weather patterns, especially in Pakistan. El Nino's consequences on agriculture, water resources, and the economy are especially severe for Pakistan. The agriculture industry, which accounts for 20% of Pakistan's GDP, is particularly at risk to dramatic changes in the weather. Pakistan's water supply is dependent on glacial meltwater from the Himalayan, Hindu Kush, and Karakoram regions.

articles.title: Congressman Don Davis pays visit to Western N.C.
articles.author: Jordan Honeycutt
articles.summary: Congressman Don Davis (NC-01) visited Western North Carolina Friday, May 23, 2025, to highlight economic recovery, regional unity, and national defense. The region was hit by Hurricane Helene in September of 2024 and an estimated $59.6 billion in damage was done. Congressman Davis attended the opening of a Walmart Supercenter in Asheville.

articles.title: Canadians Brace for Active Hurricane Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada provides timely and reliable weather information and alerts in advance of approaching tropical storms and hurricanes. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30. This season is expected to be above-average for tropical storm activity. Experts predict 13 to 19 named storms, six to 10 hurricanes, and three to five major hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean basin. There has been an increase in Category 3 to Category 5 hurricanes over the past four decades.

articles.title: Pacifica loses $50 million in FEMA funding to pay for a seawall project
articles.author: Lauren Toms
articles.summary: As coastal erosion worsens, so too does the threat to homes, businesses, and the land they sit on. Jennifer Christiansen owns a gift and pottery shop in Pacifica, California. A $50 million federal grant from FEMA's Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities (BRIC) program had been earmarked for a seawall project that locals hoped would protect the coastline. Last month, the Trump administration slashed the funding as part of a cost-saving initiative.

articles.author: Sportingnews
articles.summary: Carolina has lost the first two games to the Panthers. The team needs to win the next two games on the road to reclaim home-ice advantage. Carolina has allowed 10 goals in two games, but has scored just two in this span, while the Panthers have only scored 10.

articles.title: Title: Equal Opportunities for All!
articles.author: The Petition Site
articles.summary: Climate change is increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as hurricanes, floods and wildfires. These events can cause widespread damage, displacement, and even death due to the extreme weather.    i.e. floods, hurricanes, wildfires, and earthquakes.

articles.title: UAE tops 50C in highest May temperature on record
articles.author: The New Arab
articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates registered 50.4 degrees Celsius on Friday, the highest on record for May. Worshippers at Friday prayers reported feeling faint and some residents appeared unsteady on. The desert nation is vulnerable to climate change and is experiencing sweltering temperatures.

articles.title: Penguin poop could be our newest secret weapon against climate change
articles.author: BGR
articles.summary: Penguins' guano releases high levels of ammonia into the atmosphere. When this ammonia mixes with sulfur, it fuels the clouds around Antarctica, which could be a cause of climate change. The research was conducted by scientists at the University of Washington.

articles.title: Climate scientists are trusted globally, just not as much as other scientists – here's why
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Societies rely on scientists to guide decisions in times of uncertainty. Addressing climate change is no different for governments wanting to solve the problem.   Noyan Yilmaz, Omid Ghasemi and Ben Newell are from UNSW Sydney.

articles.title: In your opinion: Ignoring climate change is dangerous
articles.author: The Daily Star
articles.summary: People affected by climate change are rethinking where they want to live. Out of the eye is the answer for many of them, according to Daily Star's report. It's a good place to live if you're concerned about the future of the planet.

articles.title: Every summer
articles.author: Mohammad Zafar Baloch
articles.summary: It's been a scorching summer in Karachi. There are frequent power outages, water shortages and a lack of shaded public spaces. More public-awareness campaigns, provision of cooling centres and improved electricity and water management are urgently needed. Tree plantation drives and green urban planning are needed to counter the urban heat island effect.

articles.title: Coastal Futures display now at Rockaway Library
articles.summary: People from Rockaway Beach and neighboring communties were invited to a presentation called 'Coastal Futures' by University of Oregon Assistant Professor of Climate Change Resilience, Ignacio Lopez Buson and his Master of Landscape Architecture students. North Coast Communties for Watershed Protection hosted this event with participation from the Wild Salmon Center and the Oregon Coalition for an Environmental Rights Amendment.

articles.title: No threat to Pakistan as Arabian Sea system grows stronger
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: A low-pressure system in the Arabian Sea has intensified into a depression. It is located 1,058 km southeast of Karachi. The mercury is predicted to climb further on Sunday, potentially reaching 39°C. The weather is expected to get warmer on Sunday.

articles.summary: Carolina Hurricanes and Florida Panthers will be missing key players for Game 3 of the Eastern Conference final on Saturday in Sunrise, Florida. Carolina Hurricanes are leading the series 2-1. Florida Panthers are losing the series 1-0 in the tiebreaking game.

articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates recorded on Friday its highest temperature for May since it began documenting them in 2003 at a sweltering 50.4 degrees Celsius, according to the National Meteorological Agency. It was 50.3 degrees Celsius on Friday morning.

articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Carolina Hurricanes lost the first two games of the Eastern Conference Final on home ice. They lost 5-0 in Game 2. They play Game 3 on Saturday night in Florida. They have the players and the system to recover, but they have to return to what has made them successful.

articles.title: A rare desert songbird sounds 'red alert' for endangered bird species in Arizona
articles.author: Azcentral
articles.summary: Rufous hummingbirds are in danger in Arizona due to climate change. Their yearly migrations can top 7,000 miles and they are struggling with climate change in Arizona and beyond. There is a decline in Bendire's thrasher population in Arizona, which signals high levels of degradation in the ecosystem.

articles.title: Rep. Sam Liccardo pushes back against Trump cuts after $50 million loss threatens efforts to ...
articles.author: East Bay Times
articles.summary: Rep. Sam Liccardo, D-San Jose, lashed out at President Donald Trump's cuts to programs combating climate change on Friday in Pacifica. Pacifica has been left scrambling to protect critical infrastructure after a long-anticipated $50 million federal grant to address severe coastal erosion along Beach.

articles.title: Community Editorial Board: Considering Boulder's climate lawsuit
articles.author: Daily Camera
articles.summary: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled recently that a municipal lawsuit seeking to hold two of the state's largest oil and gas companies financially responsible for rising temperatures since 1983. Average temperatures in Colorado have risen 2 degrees since 1983 and are projected to rise another 2.5 to 5 degrees by 2050.

articles.title: Sea level rise expected to accelerate even if warming is limited to 1.5C: Study
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Rising seas will test humanity's resilience in the second half of the 21st century and beyond. The pace at which global oceans are rising has doubled in three decades. Limiting global warming to 1.5C would be a major achievement, according to researchers.

articles.title: UAE hits record May temperature of 51.6C
articles.author: The Peninsula
articles.summary: The highest temperature recorded over the UAE today is 51.6C in Sweihan (Al Ain) at 13:45 UAE local time (0945 GMT) on Saturday. The UAE has breached its May temperature record for the second day in a row.
